physDesc.p: This letter is 7 pages long (seq. 40-46). It is typed on something like notebook paper which has holepunches in it in different places. The words “John Gould” are written in pencil across the top of the first page. Much of the letter is difficult to read because the left margin is partially cut off.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your Friday letter reached me yesterday morning. Please forgive me for not having answered the last one I received, but the truth is I have been almost frantic getting these translations off to the press.

I am thankful to say they went off on Saturday night, and I have nothing left now but proof, which I hope will soon be over. I am a month late with the book, owing to the state of my health this summer, which prevented me from working as many hours a day as usual, but I still hope it will be out in time for the Christmas trade.

As soon as I got your letter about the Monroe-Anderson "Anthology", and incidentally Alice Henderson's journey to New York and Boston, I pondered what to do. Luckily, in the same mail came a letter from Harriet Monroe, also telling me of Alice Henderson 's journey, which enabled me to send a wire at once, asking them to be sure and let me know when she was in Boston, but not a whisper did Harriethave of the "Anthology", so very possibly you are right, and they are not going to ask me to contribute. Now as to your contributing, my dear Boy, it is very sweet of you to wish to hold back on account of their not asking me, and I appreciate this proof of your friendship very much, but I do not want you ever to feel that way. You and I will always help each other all we can, I trust, but I think we must be perfectly free agents, and at liberty to use our things to the best advantage.

I have just appeared in a little Anthologypublished by the Bonis, called "Fifty Best Poems of America", along with my revered cousin, James Russell, Longfellow, Bryant, Poe, Edwin Markham, Bliss Carman, Moody, and of all the astounding things - Arturo Giovanitti. I think with the exception of Poe's"Helen" and Giovanitti's"Walker" we may consider that the book easily contains fifty of the worst poems ever written in this country. I am represented by "A Winter Ride", a little gem which I should like to see burn in the fire. So please do not hesitate to go into the Alice HendersonAnthology , if you want to, even if shepointedly leaves me out. She doesn't like me, and I think would find a slap agreeable to administer.
What you mean by "The Trimmed Lamp Prize" I do not know, but I never go in for any prizes, so I shall certainly not compete for it, whatever it may be.

I am glad you are staying with the Aldises. They are quite interesting people. I only know them very slightly but they are most pleasant to meet and talk to and have always been most extremely nice to me.

As far as Richardand his young hopefulsare concerned, personally I feel no desire whatever to include anybody else in our Anthology. I quite agree with you that there is nobody whose work wouldadd to the quality of the bookas a whole. Elliot's "Windy Night"I have not seen. I think his three in the October "Poetry" amusing, but not very great. That sort of satire is not very difficult to do, if you only do it moderately so-so which is, I think, all he attained in these poems, and he is clearly with the Exra group, from his inclusion in "Blast" it would be the height of folly for us to make advances to him. I am writing Richard to the effect that I do not at all agree with his suggestion of one poem each from a lot of small fry, and that I think for the next two years we had better just remain ourselves, unless some very remarkable person shows up on the horizon, and I do not believe any very remarkable person is going to come for another long time, seven or eight years, or possibly longer. I think Harriet has pretty well combed England and America for promising poets, and I think everyone with a degree of talent in them has been picked up, and until the next set grow up and get old enough to write I do not believe we shall see any new and considerable names. It will merely be the perfecting and maturing of the people now writing for some little time to come. Clara Shanafelt has written one or two nice things, but Richar himself says she has not seven good ones. Now the poet who cannot scrape together seven good poems, certainly is no great shakes, and in spite of the rather nice things I have seen I do not think she would in any way add to our book , and as to Marianne Moore, I really see nothing in her whatever. I quite agree with you that Stevens's"Peter Quince" was excellent, but can see that it is quite on the cards that his other things may not be. At any rate, he does not belong to our group, and there is no necessity that I can see for hunting for people to include. I do not at all know what sort of contributions the others will send. I should think that neither Laurence nor Flint would have very brilliant ones, but there is no use worrying about that until we see them. I think that your ideas of having "Ghosts in an Old House" as one of your contributions is excellent, but we won't decide any of those things definitely until we need. As far as I am concerned, I think two moderately long poems will be my best contribution. There have been two Anthologiesnow with little things of mine in them, and I think it would be better to vary it. I think myself "A Spring Day" and a new poem "Off the Turnpike" would be best, but again, as I say, we will decide that when we meet.

I rather think that I shall not get this book off my hands for another two or three weeks, which will bring me to the first of November. Then I think I shall go on to New York and see the publishers, and be gone a week or so, but I imagine I shall be back here, settled, by the second week in November anyway, so if you arrange to be here somewhere about then we can get right to work on theAnthology . Of course I cannot say for certain, as I want to take a month's vacation if I can, but I do not expect to travel my whole month. It is just barely possible I might go to Chicagofor a few days, but I do not think there is much chance of that until later in the winter. Anyway, there are my plans as far as I can know them now. The sooner you get here the better I shall like it, but I wish you could plan to be here about the middle of November anyway, as that seems to me about the latest that we leave it about the Anthology. If I am held up again with the book , or things go slowly or anything, I will let you know.
